posts.title: Logical Operators in JavaScript
posts.text: There are three logical operators in JavaScript, &&, || and !. DescriptionUnlike in Java or C++, logical operators here can be used with non-bool type. If a value can be converted to true, the value is so-called truthy. If a value can be converted to false, the value is so-called falsy. As logical expressions are evaluated left to right, they are tested using short-circuit evaluation: Expression Returns falsy && expr false truthy && expr expr `falsy expr` expr `truthy expr` true !expr false if expr can be converted to true; otherwise, true. Expressions that can be converted to false are: NaN; null; 0; undefined; empty string(""); Replace if statement with logical ORTaking advantage of the short-circuit feature, we can easily replace if statement with || and make the code shorter. The pattern is as follow: 1234567891011121314//function 1function shortCircuitEvaluation() { doSomething() || doSomethingElse();}function equivalentEvaluation() { var flag = doSomething(); if (!flag) { doSomethingElse(); }}//function 2 :equivalent with function 1function shortCircuitEvaluation() { doSomething() || doSomethingElse();} ExampleDetermine the browser compatibility1234567domObj.onkeydown = function(e){ if(e){ //if in firefox, use e e.…… }else{ //if in IE, use event event.…… }} While, for shorter: 1234domObj.onkeydown = function(e){ var domObjEvent = e || event; domObjEvent.……} Explaination: If you are using IE, ‘e’ cannot be used as an event object. e equalsfalse while eventequals true, so event is passed todomObjEvent. If you are using firefox, ‘event’ cannot be used as an event object. e equalstrue while eventequals false, so e is passed todomObjEvent. PracticeQ:
